MANY STUDENTS UNAFFECTED BY
VALENTINE IMPULSE, POLL SHOWS
Cupid has no place in the lives
of more than sixty Hopkins students, at least in so far as sending or receiving valentines is concerned. This deplorable situation
was brought to light by a sweeping inquiry held last Wednesday.
Of one hundred and fifty-four under-graduates interviewed on the
delicate subject, sixty-four denied
any traffic in the romantc missives, while eighty-one admitted
receiving cards. Only half as.

Work on the Barnstormers production, "His' Majesty Bunker
Bean," is progressing rapidly.
Evans Rodgers will probably get
the leading part of Bunker Bean
in -the play this March. He is
well remembered for his part in
"A Tailor Made Man" last year.
There are about twenty-five men
regularly, Gordon
rehearsing
Stick, who has been in the last
two plays and who scored a great
hit in "The Galloper" in 1924,
being among the recent arrivals.
Rehearsals are being held regularly every Tuesday and Thursday
nights and Saturday and Sunday
afternoons.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 26, 1926.

GOOD NEWS—BUT--Final announcement that the New Plan will be put into
effect is, from our point of view, good news. Comment on the
scheme seems almost unnecessary; so many arguments on both
sides have appeared in our editorial and news columns within
the past year that we merely voice our approval of the Trustees
action. There can be no doubt of our position in the matter.
As usual, however, there is a fly in the ointment; no one but
President Goodnow seems to know just what plan will be used,
and Dr. Goodnow appears to be unwilling or unprepared to divulge the details of the manner in which the reorganized uni• versity will function.
We understand that several possible methods might be employed in putting Johns Hopkins upon a purely "advanced
study" basis. It is known that the university will have to provide, for a time at least, for the instruction that formally was
given in the Freshman and Sophomore years. A junior college
in connection with the advanced work, the placing of the burden
• of preliminary teaching entirely upon the city high schools, or
the continuance of the College for Teachers; any one of these
systems might be used to bridge the gap. According to reports
which are not easily verifiable, the last of these is in favor at
present.
The disadvantages of all three are too obvious to need further comment; it is our belief that the present undergraduate
school is far superior to them in every respect. When the New
Plan cs put into effect we advocate a complete break with the
past, a complete reorganization utton an entirely new basis. It
is only through the elimination of all elementary instruction
idea-of advanced work-can be made effeetivetteachers
Courses, Junior Colleges and all other ideas of similar nature
should be dropped with the undergraduate school as hindrances
and useless burdens.
If the Johns Hopkins University attempts to substitute
evil for evil there is no point to the reorganization. It is our
hope and belief that Dr. Goodnow does intend to go the limit
and make a complete change. If he does not,—why then we
would prefer the present undergraduate school with all of its
failings.
Yes, the news is good—but we still await the details of
tlie place—.

RULES ARE RULES
Athletes on the black list -are strictly barred from representing Johns Hopkins on any team. It always has been our
impression that the non-athletic activities were run on the same
basis. And yet we look around and see various men who are
in the well-known scolastie difficulties writing for publications,
serving on committees, singing. acting, and in other ways representing the university in activities. In one case a man has left
the undergraduate and continues to head an important board.
We hold no personal animus to any of these men, but rules
should work both ways.

All letters intended for publication
must be concise, written in ink on
regular letter size paper, on one side
only.
No attention will be paid to anonymous letters, but names signed as an •
evidence of good faith will not be

freest discussion of matters of general
interest.

FORMER EDITOR OBJECTS
To the Editor of the News-Letter:
Dear Sir:
Your recent appeal to the Student Council strikes me as premature and inconsistent with
. your vows of office. If I.remember correctly, on taking over the
pen of the editor-in:chief from
the failing fingers of your predec'essor you vowed not to pretend
to be the mouthpiece of the student body. You promised to give
your own opinions _only.
Viewed in such a light your editorial on unlimited cuts seems
to me to bear little relation to
the Student Council. When the
undergraduate body through its
class officers expresses a wish
that Seniors and Juniors be allowed to study at their leisure
the Student Council will be delighted to consider the matter.
Until then, however, I, at least,
shall continue to consider your
editorials as your personal views
rather than the mutterings of
that rather intangible personality
—the student body.
Yours sincerely,
ALGER HISS.

MANY STUDENTS UNAFFECTED BY
VALENTINE IMPULSE, POLL SHOWS
Cupid has no place in the lives
of more than sixty Hopkins students, at least in so far as sending or receiving valentines is concerned. This deplorable situation
was brought to light by a sweeping inquiry held last Wednesday.
Of one hundred and fifty-four under-graduates interviewed on the
delicate subject, sixty-four denied
any traffic in the romantc missives, while eighty-one admitted
receiving cards. Only half as.

afternoons.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 26, 1926.

GOOD NEWS—BUT--Final announcement that the New Plan will be put into
effect is, from our point of view, good news. Comment on the
scheme seems almost unnecessary; so many arguments on both
sides have appeared in our editorial and news columns within
the past year that we merely voice our approval of the Trustees
action. There can be no doubt of our position in the matter.
As usual, however, there is a fly in the ointment; no one but
President Goodnow seems to know just what plan will be used,
and Dr. Goodnow appears to be unwilling or unprepared to divulge the details of the manner in which the reorganized uni• versity will function.
We understand that several possible methods might be employed in putting Johns Hopkins upon a purely "advanced
study" basis. It is known that the university will have to provide, for a time at least, for the instruction that formally was
given in the Freshman and Sophomore years. A junior college
in connection with the advanced work, the placing of the burden
• of preliminary teaching entirely upon the city high schools, or
the continuance of the College for Teachers; any one of these
systems might be used to bridge the gap. According to reports
which are not easily verifiable, the last of these is in favor at
present.
The disadvantages of all three are too obvious to need further comment; it is our belief that the present undergraduate
school is far superior to them in every respect. When the New
Plan cs put into effect we advocate a complete break with the
past, a complete reorganization utton an entirely new basis. It
is only through the elimination of all elementary instruction
idea-of advanced work-can be made effeetivetteachers
Courses, Junior Colleges and all other ideas of similar nature
should be dropped with the undergraduate school as hindrances
and useless burdens.
If the Johns Hopkins University attempts to substitute
evil for evil there is no point to the reorganization. It is our
hope and belief that Dr. Goodnow does intend to go the limit
and make a complete change. If he does not,—why then we
would prefer the present undergraduate school with all of its
failings.
Yes, the news is good—but we still await the details of
tlie place—.

RULES ARE RULES
Athletes on the black list -are strictly barred from representing Johns Hopkins on any team. It always has been our
impression that the non-athletic activities were run on the same
basis. And yet we look around and see various men who are
in the well-known scolastie difficulties writing for publications,
serving on committees, singing. acting, and in other ways representing the university in activities. In one case a man has left
the undergraduate and continues to head an important board.
We hold no personal animus to any of these men, but rules
should work both ways.

FORMER EDITOR OBJECTS
To the Editor of the News-Letter:
Dear Sir:
Your recent appeal to the Student Council strikes me as premature and inconsistent with
. your vows of office. If I.remember correctly, on taking over the
pen of the editor-in:chief from
the failing fingers of your predec'essor you vowed not to pretend
to be the mouthpiece of the student body. You promised to give
your own opinions _only.
Viewed in such a light your editorial on unlimited cuts seems
to me to bear little relation to
the Student Council. When the
undergraduate body through its
class officers expresses a wish
that Seniors and Juniors be allowed to study at their leisure
the Student Council will be delighted to consider the matter.
Until then, however, I, at least,
shall continue to consider your
editorials as your personal views
rather than the mutterings of
that rather intangible personality
—the student body.
Yours sincerely,
ALGER HISS.
